concept.title: Cell: content and format
concept.shortdesc: An explanation of the key difference between the content and format (appearance) of a cell.

conbody.p: A cell has a content and a format. It is very important to keep this difference in mind! A poor understanding of this is often the source of errors. As an example see the following figure. In the cells A1:A10 always the same number 40299 has been entered. So these cells have the same content. Yet they still look different and that's because the formatting of these cells is different.

fig.title: Example of cells with the same content and different formatting

image.alt: Example of cells with the same content and different formatting.

conbody.p: Looking at the figure it is difficult to see what the format and what the content is. Content and formatting are two different things.
conbody.note: Make sure you do not type the formatting when entering data in a cell. For example if you type in cell A9 40.299 hours, then is considered as text and not a number. And because it is a text you cannot calculate with the content. It is possible to only enter the number and then format the cell so that it has the appearance as shown. The content of the cell is than a number with which you can make calculations.
The preferred method is first enter the content in the cell and give the cell the desired format after that.
